4:32 Ok STOP, just STOP this misinformation train right here, H. pylori is still being studied by science. The studies has shown wide range of contradicting results, and none have ever claimed it causes 95% of all stomach cancer. In fact much cancer research shows the exact opposite, "Several studies have detected an inverse relationship between H. pylori infection and gastric cardia cancer. The possibility of an inverse relationship between the bacterium and gastric cardia cancer is supported by the corresponding decrease in H. pylori infection rates in Western countries during the past century—the result of improved hygiene and widespread antibiotic use—and the increase in rates of gastric cardia cancer in these same regions." ~The National Cancer Institute.
The most we have been able to tell is there is a rare mutation in some H. pylori that is classified as cagA-positive. Epidemiologic evidence suggests that infection with cagA-positive strains is especially associated with an increased risk of non-cardia gastric cancer, but again there are other studies that show contradicting results.

for the first point, a youtube channel called lemmino gave a very plausible scenario rundown. I remember seeing it a few years ago.

I think with the dyatlov pass incident, the radiation is a red herring since one of them worked at a nuclear facility, and they used lanterns with thorium.

I think the avalanche theory burying their tent and sending them into the night is the most likely. There’s no other reason to cut your way OUT of a tent rather than just crawl out.
As far as the missing clothes go, I think the subzero temperatures caused them to shed their layers as they began to succumb to hypothermia. It’s called paradoxical undressing, because the body misinterprets the hypothermia as overheating. The missing eyes and tongues are probably just from carrion and canine scavengers.

At the end of the day, they just weren’t equipped for that kind of trip. It’s seems clear they panicked and ran to get away from another cascade of snow, so then they found themselves lost and stranded in a subzero wilderness.

I also guessed the same about the avalanche, because anything else wouldn't have made sense!
But I was more surprised that it wasn't the immediate conclusion in the first place.
The diatlov pass case has been solved and it had nothing to do with an avalanch

In 1845 British North America was the precursor to Canada 1867, and those specific territories were then known as The Northwest Territories ( of BNA ). It is now within Nunavut. The Inuit Homelands.

The Dyatlov Pass incident was not an avalanche and I don't understand why people continue to think it was.
The investigation report very clearly states that snow around the area was largely undisturbed and most importantly the tent itself was not disturbed the way an avalanche would before or after the hikers cut themselves out and it was only covered with loose, fresh snow when discovered.
Combined with the burn marks on the bodies and the insides of the tent, the most likely theory is that the modified camping stove the hikers used malfunctioned, sparking a fire and filling the tent with smoke. Some of the hikers where also intoxicated at the time, so presumably panic broke out, they overreacted, damaging the tent more than necessary. It's still not clear why they then abandoned the campsite for the woods though.

Finally the radiation was only found on two of the bodies, both of who were physics student working at a nuclear physics lab.

As to Dyatlov Pass I can believe the avalanche theory - but I would add an additional possibility to the assumptions, that being the likely chance that a large, hungry carnivorous animal or pack of animals were attacking them in the tent, and in the excited melee of a potential feeding frenzy they managed to weaken the snow and trigger the avalanche. This idea seems to me to cover a lot, such as why the campers escaped the tent so frantically, how the gruesome injuries came about, why they only took what little clothing they had on, etc.
The dyatlov pass incident was not an avalanche. It wasn’t supernatural. But something weird definitely happened

The problem with the Dylatov Pass hypothesis is that there was no evidence of an avalanche. The only damage to the tent was the cut they had made in it. (Old school tent had a button entrance. In an emergency it was quicker to cut the side, which could be repaired later.) One other hypothesis was that an extreme down draft made a sound like an avalanche, which made them run to avoid it. The crush injuries were only on those who were later found in a gully, and likely were caused by them falling through a snow cover. The missing tongue can be easily explained away by predation. The downdraft was partly proven by a similar incident in the US, where one person survived, and was able to describe what happened.

Similar to Frozen, Jurassic Park determined the average running speed for a T-Rex. One scientist had calculated a running speed, but did a bad job, and estimated a speed that was way too fast. When the Jurassic Park team tried to create a running CGI T-Rex, it looked silly at that running speed, so they slowed it down until it looked normal. Turns out, the speed Jurassic Park landed on was pretty accurate. The Jurassic Park situation encouraged other scientists to check the first guy's work, and with better techniques they landed on about the same running speed that Jurassic Park did. Because of that, scientists now frequently use CGI models to test their hypothesized speeds and movement patterns for extinct animals.

About the Franklin expedition and lead poisoning: Wouldn't acute lead poisoning not make much impact on the bones and teeth of the expedition? What seems to be described in the study would be the result of chronic lead exposure, not acute. The manner in which the expidition handled themselves points more towards acute lead poisoning or at least other mental impairment as wasted effort on dragging all sorts of unnecessary baggage with them including: A whole life boat, a writing desk, curtain rods, scented soaps, button polish and books.
Acute lead poisoning has a lot of awful symptoms, from muscle weakness to sever intestinal problems... but the worst is probably the neurological. Cognitive function diminishes severly and the victim is dazed and confused, not a good state to be in in a survival situation. Physical effort can still be sustained ... but physical effort without coherent thought behind it is a detriment in a survival situation.

The Dyatlov's group was assassinated by CIA operatives, in a failed KGB sting operation, Dyatlov was a KGB officer, assigned to the Ministry of the Middle Machinery (Nuclear power and nuclear technology) and lived in a number of MMMs closed cities, including Lermontov, North Caucasus and Sverdlovsk.

The case file and the 2 autopsy reports are available in the book of investigation by Alexei Rakitin. The proof is out in the open and contained in the CIA archives, accessible online.

Concerning the Dyatlov pass incident I find the idea proposed in lemmino's video more believable: some mistake with the homemade furnace the campers had in the tent caused a fire and panic, they escaped out of the tent to escape the smoke was then stuck outside in the middle of winter without shelter, this would also explain the damage consistent with smoke inhalation and why the footprints they left outside were so orderly.

If you're going to burn your letters or other documents, be sure to do it safely and completely. Famously, the Hayman Fire in Colorado was started by a forest ranger burning a letter from a lover in a firepit - resulting in numerous lost houses, forest burning, animal deaths, and so on. Do it at a high enough temperature so that the paper actually is burned - incompletely burned documents can still easily be read.

On Napoleon, finding some evidence of a precursor of stomach cancer is not close to finding evidence of stomach cancer.  Also, the presentation in this video suggests that the poisoning theory depended on an international cabal, which is ludicrous, and clearly intended to make the countervailing case appear ludicrous.  The actual leading theory that historians entertain as far as poisoning goes is that the British officer who was in charge of security on St Helena didn't want to be exiled on this tiny rock in the middle of the South Atlantic with Nappy, so he poisoned him to get out of there himself.  I'm not saying it's true, just that it is still equally as plausible of an explanation.
